p.span:
The SPEAKER ( Hon.
Tony Smith ) took the chair at 10:00, made an acknowledgement of country and read prayers.
COMMITTEES
Petitions Committee
Report

Mr O'DOWD (Flynn—Deputy Nationals Whip) (10:01): I present the 26th report of the Petitions Committee for the 46th parliament together with 46 petitions and 18 ministerial responses to the petitions previously presented.
Chair Mr Ken O'Dowd MP
Deputy Chair Hon Justine Elliot MP
Mrs Bridget Archer MP
Ms Lisa Chesters MP
Ms Gladys Liu MP
Mr Julian Simmonds MP
Mr James Stevens MP
Ms Susan Templeman MP

span.span: Report summarising the petitions and Ministerial responses being presented.
The committee met in private session on 21 April 2021
1. The committee resolved to present the following petitions in accordance with standing order 207:

p.span: From 10 petitioners - requesting the Australian Broadcasting Corporation be defunded (EN2511)
From 4 petitioners - regarding a royal commission into suicide and depression (EN2515)
From 5551 petitioners - requesting changes to the means testing for parental leave pay (EN2516)
From 31 petitioners - regarding the category of 'special witness' in court proceedings (EN2521)
From 13 petitioners - regarding healthcare funding (EN2523)
From 4 petitioners - requesting the removal of 'Basic Religious Charity' category from legislation administered by the Australian Charities and Not- for-profits Commission (EN2526)
From 1578 petitioners - requesting an extension of the JobKeeper support for people working in the travel industry (EN2527)
From 36 petitioners - regarding funding of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (EN2530)
From 101 petitioners - regarding transgender and non-binary rights (EN2533)
From 47 petitioners - regarding visa rules for permanent residents (EN2540)
From 6274 petitioners - regarding travel ban exemptions for parents of Australian citizens and permanent residents (EN2543)
From 1009 petitioners - regarding a federal election (EN2544)
From 6 petitioners - regarding the Migration Act (EN2545)
From 72 petitioners - requesting the cashless debit card trial and rollout be halted (EN2548)
From 837 petitioners - regarding the travel ban for international students (EN2556)
From 248 petitioners - regarding veterans' exposure to carcinogenic dioxins during the Vietnam War (EN2557)
From 73 petitioners - regarding the security of the Jetstar booking system (EN2558)
From 144 petitioners - regarding the reclassification of homeopathic medications under the Agvet code (EN2559)
From 2 petitioners - regarding copyright law amendments (EN2561)
From 28 petitioners - regarding amendments to the Veterans' Entitlement Act and its definition of evidence (EN2562)
From 2 petitioners - regarding aged care funding (EN2564)
From 10 petitioners - regarding the regulation of house prices (EN2566)
From 18 petitioners - regarding amendments to the Veterans' Entitlement Act and its treatment of obesity (EN2567)
From 13 petitioners - requesting a boycott of the 2022 Beijing Winter Olympic Games (EN2572)
From 7 petitioners - requesting mandatory identification for voters (EN2574)
From 28 petitioners - regarding amendments to the Veterans' Entitlement Act (EN2581)
From 1 petitioner - regarding overpopulation impacts on Australian Government Bond returns (EN2582)
From 1 petitioner - regarding overpopulation impacts on superannuation returns (EN2583)
From 3 petitioners - regarding the national health and physical education curriculum (EN2584)
From 268 petitioners - requesting changes to the Defence-related Claims Act to mirror supports provided under the Military Rehabilitation and Compensation Act (EN2585)
From 199 petitioners - requesting amendments to the Interactive Gambling Act to legalise online poker (EN2592)
From 270 petitioners - requesting all forms of gambling advertisements be banned (EN2593)
From 54 petitioners - regarding foreign ownership of land (EN2594)
From 22 petitioners - regarding a ban on advertising gambling at sport events (EN2595)
From 17 petitioners - regarding a code of conduct for Members of Parliament (EN2597)
From 27 petitioners - regarding influenza vaccinations (EN2598)
From 87 petitioners - requesting the House remove prayers from the standing orders (EN2599)
From 8 petitioners - requesting the cost of land be included in the consumer price index (EN2600)
From 8 petitioners - regarding the restriction of childcare benefits (EN2602)
From 6 petitioners - regarding the Committee on the Rights of the Child and the Convention on the Rights of the Child (EN2603)
From 39 petitioners - requesting National Relay Service registration be made optional (EN2604)
From 33 petitioners - regarding the Veterans' Entitlement Act (EN2605)
From 441 petitioners - requesting legislation on equal employment (EN2607)
From 77 petitioners - requesting the distribution of the AstraZeneca vaccine be paused and subject to further research (EN2609)
From 1837 petitioners - requesting a partial reopening of international borders (EN2611)
From 83 petitioners - regarding the introduction of a Halal certification body (EN2612)

span.span: The following ministerial responses to petitions were received:
Ministerial responses received by the Committee on 12 May 2021

p.span: From the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Infrastructure, Transport and Regional Development - to a petition regarding the Perth Airport banksia woodlands, wetlands and Aboriginal heritage sites (EN1823)
From the Attorney General - to a petition regarding the Royal Commission into Institutional Responses to Child Sexual Abuse (EN1856)
From the Attorney-General - to a petition requesting majority consent on determining state of disasters or emergencies and for international treaties (EN1916)
From the Attorney-General - to a petition requesting a Royal Commission into Australia's news media (EN1980)
From the Assistant Minister for Electoral Matters - to a petition requesting an independent federal anti-corruption body (EN1982)
From the Minister for Government Services - to a petition regarding a universal basic income program (EN2045)
From the Attorney General - to a petition requesting a stop to employers demanding a criminal history check (EN2071)
From the Minister for Families and Social Services - to a petition regarding changes to the Coronavirus Supplement, Carer Payments, Disability Support Pension and Temporary visas (EN2087)
From the Attorney General - to a petition requesting a royal commission into the treatment of people with disability (EN2113)
From the Minister for Veterans' Affairs - to a petition regarding reparation payments for instances of serious abuse (EN2128)
From the Assistant Minister for Waste Reduction and Environmental Management - to a petition regarding a uniformed recycling industry in Australia (EN2158)
From the Minister for Health and Aged Care - to a petition requesting Medicare to cover emergency ambulance transportation (EN2164)
From the Minister for Trade, Tourism and Investment - to a petition requesting an increase in tariffs and continued economic sanctions against China (EN2269)
From the Minister for Health and Aged Care - to a petition requesting an Australian Centre for Disease Control (EN2274)
From the Minister for Health and Aged Care - to a petition regarding legislation preventing the Australian Government from enacting mandatory COVID-19 vaccines (EN2314)
From the Attorney-General - to a petition requesting a royal commission into the Federation of Australia (EN2349)
From the Assistant Treasurer - to a petition regarding the Australian Government's interference in the property market (EN2379)
From the Assistant Minister for Customs, Community Safety and Multicultural Affairs - to a petition regarding airsoft gun parts and accessories (EN2400)
PETITIONS
Mr O'DOWD (Flynn—Deputy Nationals Whip) (10:01): I present the following petitions:
Australian Broadcasting Corporation

The ABC has become a media organisation bereft of fair reporting and the undertones in their news reports is not based on fair standards. The ABC is biased towards the left wing of politics and as such is not representative of the people who fund it, the taxpayers.
We therefore ask the House to defund the ABC and disband it.
from 10 citizens (Petition No. EN2511)
Mental Health

There has been too many suicides in the ADF and Depression as states from a many ex ADF members and Pollies such as Pauline Hanson Craig Kelly Malcom Roberts, Andrew Hastie just to name a couple. It would be help full those who suffer and to there families.
We therefore ask the House to vote a yes to have a Royal Commission into suicides and Depression. Thank you.
from 4 citizens (Petition No. EN2515)
Paid Parental Leave Scheme

The current Paid Parental Leave Scheme is not only disastrously underfunded, but is also discriminatory towards families where the female is the main breadwinner. The Policy is tied to the woman's income, not the family income. This means that if you have two families on the same combined income, one family may be eligible, whereas the other is not. If, for example, I make 160,000 the year prior to delivery and my partner earns 50,000, we would not be eligible for the payment, however, if I earned 50,000 and he earned 500,000,000 then we would be eligible -> it is ludicrous!

I am a female General Practitioner and although I see discrimination on a daily basis in my work based on my gender, I am stunned and appalled that there exists legislation that underscores this discrimination. How can we expect the same working conditions as our male counterparts when our own government will not support our legitimacy?

A recent Bill was brought to the senate in June 2020 to resolve this inequality. Unfortunately, the amendments were not supported by the government or One Nation Senators and so did not pass. Is the government truly committed to delivery on measures announced in their Women's Economic Security Statement, or are these just empty words?
We therefore ask the House to change the means testing for the Parental Leave Pay from being based on the income of the mother alone, to that of the family.
from 5551 citizens (Petition No. EN2516)
Australian Courts
There is a disparity in the legal system between the two genders which is leading to the frustration of equity in representation in Australian courts.
The female that alleges anything against a man is termed a "special witness" and her statement against him is taken as fact by the court.
This prevents the female's statement of events to be challenged or questioned for legitimacy and there is no requirement for the female to substantiate her claims.
The male making a statement is open to challenge, with the onus placed on him to substantiate his claims with evidence.
The male is not treated in an equitable manner or afforded the legal status that the female is given.
We therefore ask the House to ensure that the "special witness" feature/status offered to a female is removed ensuring parity in the legal framework.
from 31 citizens (Petition No. EN2521)
Health Care
Health care in Australia is a disgrace. Too much money is being taken by for profit organisations. Instead of Actual Healthcare. The government are encouraging this system
We therefore ask the House to seriously reform the Healthcare system . By funding more public healthcare.
from 13 citizens (Petition No. EN2523)
Charitable Organisations

The focus of this petition is to improve safety for children in Australia. Democracy depends on religious charities demonstrating transparent finances and governance, particular as recipients of government funding. Under ACNC Act, 'Basic Religious Charities' are exempt from certain reporting requirements and allowed lower Governance Standards. Religious Charities with BRC status are not required to answer financial information questions or submit annual financial reports to ACNC or comply with ACNC governance standards. As most Religions function without a democratic, diverse or accountable elected Board, finance and governance is undertaken by autocratic management. Board members are 'selected' advisory. For example, a Diocesan Bishop is often the sole autocratic manager of billions of dollars of government grants. Religious Charities and Entities receiving government funding must be subject to same regulatory standards as NFP/governments, industry and business. Any religious charity who is a recipient of government funding must be register on Australian Government Lobby Register. After horrific findings of Australian Royal Commission into Institutional Responses to Child Sex Abuse, large and international religious charities must be subject to robust reporting requirements, public accountability, greater regulatory oversight and financial accountability. . We therefore ask the House to abolish 'Basic Religious Charity Category exemptions from the ACNC Act and improve religious charity governance in line provisions under the ACNC Act to improve safety for children.
Thank you for your interest and involvement
Request:
We therefore ask the House to Calls to Abolish Basic Religious Charity Category and exemptions under ACNC Act.
from 4 citizens (Petition No. EN2526)
JobKeeper Payment: Tourism Industry

Border closures mean significant if not total lack of revenue for travel agents and tour operators. The wage support in our industry needs to continue at least up until the federal government opens the international borders and beyond for severely affected businesses.

We therefore ask the House to extend the current jobkeeper wage support for people in the travel industry still suffering from the federal governments border policy relating to the Covid-19 pandemic. As the borders remain closed the support should continue.
from 1578 citizens (Petition No. EN2527)
Australian Broadcasting Corporation
I am sick to death of the bias ABC and its Tax payer funded media outlets blasting their one way single minded woke garbage on the general public, not just in Australia.
We are now in a world where our services have been sold off to corporations however some such things have managed to hang out and not dry. The ABC.

They are a one way media organisation that has not adapted the 21st century. That been two way open communication. An example of this would be to go to YouTube and try leave a comment on their misleading dangerous news articles that pretty much instead of defending Australian values and legal systems endeavors to destroy. 1st been freedom of speech. No matter what you tune in to from the ABC it is always the same propaganda stemming from Marxist ideologies that fill the air waves. I as a tax paying Australian today say NO MORE!
We therefore ask the House to Stop funding the ABC.
from 36 citizens (Petition No. EN2530)
Gender and Sexual Orientation

Transgender and non binary people are at increasingly high risk of being discriminated against by federal, state and local agencies through harmful actions such as the motion brought to the senate by Senator Malcolm Roberts and accepted by the senate on 16 March 2021. These actions can lead to increased instances of suicide, self harm and mental health issues amongst an already vulnerable group of people. The language that Senator Roberts outlines in his motion, such as gestational/non-gestational parent, chest-feeding, lactating parent, birthing/non-birthing parent should not be something regulated by government officials, but should be a personal choice left up to the individuals.

We therefore ask the House to acknowledge that the motion presented by Senator Malcom Roberts and accepted by the Senate on March 16 2021 will be harmful to the transgender and non-binary communities and to reject all such motions in the House of Representatives.
from 101 citizens (Petition No. EN2533)
Student Visas

Why the Australian government keeps on changing the rules and makes it so tough to get a position of permanent residency on every year. As international students are the highest tax payers in Australia they are still negligible at all sort of services. We came here in search of better life or better lifestyle even though we cant afford education here. But after we finish our education here we cant able to find the respective job here in Australia because we are not PR holders how possibly can a student get a PR without having a job here according to Australian visa rules. This is so insane countries like Canada and USA has soften their visa rules. Majority of students who planned to come here has changed their destination to Canada or so called countries. We paid alot of money here we cant go back, we cant take second chances and we cant let down our parents who send us here with lots of dreams in their minds. I here, want to fight for the related issues in Australia I need support from everyone who think that international students who come here should have a better life as well. Thank you

We therefore ask the House to please change the visa rules if at least they don't need us as a permanent residents. At least change some rules to extend visa period and taking an ethical law to give importance to international students in their related field jobs
from 47 citizens (Petition No. EN2540)
COVID-19: International Travel

Due to the current travel ban, parents of Australian citizens and Permanent residents are not allowed to enter Australia. Families have been separated, which is causing mental and emotional stress. Parents are a key part of an emotional support system for immigrants and their families, and as newer members of Australian society immigrants often have no other support networks. Family re-union is critical and urgent for many Australian citizens and Permanent residents.

We therefore ask the House to consider travel exemptions to the parents of Australian citizens and Permanent residents. The parents should be sponsored and supported and will not be a burden on the government or the community. A mandatory 14-day paid quarantine at designated facilities should be applied so to protect the health of the Australian community.
from 6274 citizens (Petition No. EN2543)
Federal Election
The ability of the current Government to continue with the confidence of the People/Electors/Constituents is no longer possible.
We therefore ask the House to ensure:
1. all steps are taken to deliver a Federal Election to the People of Australia immediately.
2. the election is completed within the time frame normally allotted to an election once an election is called.
3. the AEC is provided with the powers/authority to prevent ineligible, unlawful and misleading incidents leading up to and during the election process.
4. the AEC is provided with the ability to disqualify political Candidates/Parties that are party to ineligible, unlawful and misleading incidents leading up to and during the election process.
5. the AEC is provided with the ability to prosecute any individuals/organisations found to be party to ineligible, unlawful and misleading activities leading up to and during the election process.
from 1009 citizens (Petition No. EN2544)
Migration

Section 501 of the Migration Act 1958 goes against basic Human Rights which Australia ought to abide by. This statutory provision does not allow natural justice (under subsections (3) to (3B)). This provision also has a Character Test which is discriminatory. For example, for a visa holder who has changed his or her life around in a positive manner, and a previous criminal conviction history was a long period of time ago, this is not taken into account when the government-official assesses one's character. For many New Zealand citizens, who have spent the majority of their life residing in Australia, this Character-test (and other statutory provisions of the Migration Act) is discriminatory against them. This results in cruel and swift deportation of New Zealand citizens, back to New Zealand, many of whom are of Maori and/or Pacific-Island descent. This, therefore, highlights racial discrimination underlying these particular visa statutory-provisions too.

We therefore ask the House to refer this Petition to the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Human Rights, for a review and report on the Migration Act 1958 (especially section 501), in light of the Petition Reasons. We also ask that the House to comply with its International Obligations under the ICCPR (Article 7 right to not be subjected to cruel treatment or punishment; Article 10 right to be treated with humanity and respect for the inherent dignity of the human person; Article 24 right to not be discriminated as to race and Article 26 right to be free from discrimination.
from 6 citizens (Petition No. EN2545)
Welfare
Immediately end the draconian, unlawful, discriminatory and harmful Indue Cashless Debit Card trial and rollout.

The Cashless Debit Card has proven to be a failure despite what the LNP would try and have people believe. It has caused untold harm in the areas it has been trialled including but not limited to an increase in homelessness and suicide. I'm am hereby demanding that the "trial" be immediately halted.
We therefore ask the House to immediately end the Indue Cashless Debit trial in ALL trial sites
from 72 citizens (Petition No. EN2548)
COVID-19: International Travel
International students who were outside of the Australia when the travel ban was in-placed have not been able to enter Australia for almost a year.
We are like the forgotten minority, and have to pay the full tuition fee while taking the courses completely online.
The Australian government should lift the ban for students who have been vaccinated and tested negative for the COVID-19.
We therefore ask the House to lift the travel ban for international students that have been vaccinated and tested negative for the COVID-19 so that they can enter Australia.
from 837 citizens (Petition No. EN2556)
Veterans

Members serving in HMA Ships during Vietnam War were exposed to carcinogenic dioxins when contaminated riverine water was distilled to produce potable water, supposedly fit for human consumption. Sadly, this was not the case.

Seven diseases accepted by the Department of Veterans Affairs (DVA) reflect this concern. Yet five diseases still exist where DVA do not accept the Factor "that must as a minimum exist before it can be said that a reasonable hypothesis has been raised connecting (disease) with the circumstances of a person's relevant service is:
On land in Vietnam
At sea in Vietnamese waters, or

On board a vessel and consuming potable water supplied on that vessel when the water supply had been produced by evaporative distillation of estuarine waters for a cumulative period of at least 30 days, at least five years before the clinical onset of (disease)."

We therefore ask the House to Refer the true circumstances of the above service in Vietnam - and Vietnamese waters - to the Minister most concerned, with a recommendation that the following diseases have the Factor quoted inserted into the Statement of Principle for:
Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia,
Type 2 Diabetes,
Ischemic Heart Disease,
Hypothyroidism.
from 248 citizens (Petition No. EN2557)
Jetstar

Jetstar's Booking System is not secure. Bookings are changed without the authority of the person making the original booking. Incorrect or inaccurate information is used to change bookings. Email addresses and Phone Numbers used are non-existent. Contact Names are misspelt. Jetstar has no Identity Verification system to validate the accuracy of information. Jetstar is mining personal data for fraudulent use. Jetstar monitors social media and collects data to use against complaints.

The Call Centre directs Victims on a path that claims it is the Victims fault. It refuses to consider the problem may be within the Company itself. All attempts to escalate concerns are denied. The Call Centre says it is the highest point of contact, then says the matter is not open to further queries and that it will ignore any future contact. Emails to executives are ignored.
Many Australians have lost considerable time and money through the failure of Jetstar to secure the Booking System.
We therefore ask the House to set up a Parliamentary Inquiry into the Failure of Security in the Jetstar Booking system, inviting responses from affected Australians.

The Terms of Reference should include, if Jetstar Executives direct the Call Centre to insist on Vouchers, and refuse refunds for bookings cancelled by Jetstar, Legality of data mining of personal Data by Jetstar on Social Media, Call Centre Staff investigated for maladministration, and inappropriate use of client data. Consider if any crime has occurred, and refer the matter to the relevant Authority.
from 73 citizens (Petition No. EN2558)
Complementary Medicines
Currently it is a "criminal offence" to provide unregistered natural medicines and other modalities to pets according to the Ag Vet Code.

The APVMA who is funded by the drug company (Ag Vet) has put natural alternative supplements , herbs and homeopathics under the banner of dangerous chemical drugs. The (TGA approved as "low risk") remedies according to Ag Vet Code need to be tested and approved.
However, the only way to be approved with the Ag Vet code is that the toxicities levels of the product or homeopathic remedy needs to registered and monitor.

Therefore, it is impossible to be get a approved laboratory test, as there are no toxicities that can be measured, they do not exist in homeopathic (same homeopathics given to humans, as approved TGA low risk)
We therefore ask the House to amend the Ag Vet code to allow " non toxic" alternative naturopathic medicines and therapies for animals, as low risk, therefore do not need to be .
Example :
Medicines and TGA classifications for Humans
Australia has a two-tiered system for the regulation of medicines, including complementary medicines:
• Higher risk medicines must be registered on the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods (ARTG), which involves individually evaluating the quality, safety and effectiveness of the product.
• Lower risk medicines containing pre-approved, low-risk ingredients and that make limited claims can be listed on the ARTG.
Listed medicines (unlike registered medicines), we do not assess each listed medicine for efficacy before it goes onto the market.
from 144 citizens (Petition No. EN2559)
Intellectual Property

Copyright holders are given a privilege of protection against illegal copying of their works, but in a digital age where providing access to works such as books, visual art, TV shows, films and video games is easier than ever and often with negligible cost to the publisher, this privilege has been abused by locking up artistic works, often with little to no justification. Countless older works are either only available second hand (often in formats incompatible with modern devices) or disappearing entirely. Copyright exists with the expectation that the public should have legal commercial access to copyrighted works in some form so copyright holders can be compensated. It is unfair to the public to be expected to wait 70+ years for a work to become public domain just to access it legally, and lack of legal access is extremely harmful for the preservation of art and culture. Copyright holders have little excuse to not use their copyrights as the law intended, not providing legal access to copyrighted works essentially breaks the social contract between copyright holders and the public.

We therefore ask the House to introduce a "use/sell it or lose it" clause to copyright law, where a published work becomes part of the public domain if it ceases to be reasonably accessible to purchase (or even for free if the publisher sees fit), use, and/or stream digitally (though ideally works should be available for permanent ownership) for a certain amount of time without reasonable justification.
from 2 citizens (Petition No. EN2561)
Veterans

The phrase "sound medical-scientific evidence" (SMSE) and its associated meaning as per Section 5AB of the Veterans' Entitlement Act (VEA), has been drafted in such a manner that it provides the Repatriation Medical Authority (RMA), with the arbitrary power to effectively turn "information" into material with equal probative value of "evidence" as per the Evidence Act 1995 (EA). Only under the VEA the RMA can do this without regard, consideration, or exposure to the procedural safeguards that were installed in the EA.
Information listed at VEA s5AB(2)(a) would only be considered evidence under the EA, if its adduced with the EA s177 Certificate of Expert Evidence safeguard.

SMSE is used as the basis to construct the Statements of Principals (SOP'S), a very powerful and overarching legislative instrument under which the majority of determination on claims and applications are made by the Repatriation Commission. The SOP's dictate what "must exist" before an injury, disease or death is connected with the circumstances of a person's relevant service.
The ability for the RMA to arbitrarily determine what is effectively "evidence", sets in place processes which arguably result in breach of natural justice.

We believe an amendment need be made to the VEA in order to expose the SOP's to the procedural safeguard of the EA, and subsequently restore natural justice to the relevant determination processes of the VEA.
We therefore ask the House to initiate such processes to cause such amendment to the VEA that will result in "sound medical-scientific evidence" being replaced with "evidence".
from 28 citizens (Petition No. EN2562)
Aged Care

Australian Federal Gov to fund AGED CARE as all other welfare with not extra levies or taxes. why should jobseekers or other welfare, especially the NDIS get everything funded or given to them for free & pay not tax or even the pay the Medicare Levy? Outrageously continually subsidizing many with housing, medication, energy & many other assistances. Many have are young or never ever paid any tax or the Medicare Levy while many older people have for years paid their taxes & the Medicare Levy BUT ARE BEING ASKED TO CONTRIBUTE AGAIN. WHY? Now some polaticns are even suggesting for workers not to get the super increases but be directed to aged care?

How about cutting polaticns super from 15% to 9.5% & this be put towards aged care, also cut number of public servants & public servants wages who earn more then the Prime Minister. SELL THE ABC & SBS, make everyone pay their Medicare Levy (except the aged pensioners & Aust. students), stop subsidizing the solar panels & wind turbines, stop paying money to Chinese W.H.O., Left wing United Nations, Paris Agreement & Globolist world economic forum, any foreign bank funds All foreign aid, stop funding refugee activists & lawyers & get rid of all State Governments (referendum) ect.
ALL THESE & MANY OTHER CUTS COULD FUND A VERY GOOD AGED CARE.
We therefore ask the House to FULLY FUND AGED CARE WITHOUT ANY LEVIES/TAXES AS THE GOV. FUNDS THE NDIS & ALL AUST. WELFARE SYSTEM
WHY SHOULD AGED CARE BE TREATED DIFFERENTLY?
from 2 citizens (Petition No. EN2564)
Housing Affordability

We are middle-income earners with two kids and dreaming to have our own house but despite having jobs we are unable to afford it. The house pricing in Australia is still going up but the salary doesn't. I want the government to act on this issue as many Australians are suffering on how to buy a house to live in. I saw a lot of people in the auction but only 3-5 can bid because it's an unimaginable price that is just manipulated by the agents and most investors.

How can we compete with them? Please regulate the price on what low and middle-income earners can afford and remove the investors on the housing market. When some became greedy, others need to suffer. Many of us have to travel a lot to get to work because we can only afford a house in remote areas. This problem is diving us to move far where we can not find a job and where people become poor.
Investors have a lot of property and why can't the government just help us to get one? This is not fair for many and I hope it's not to late to help us and to live a normal life to our country

We therefore ask the House to regulate the price on the housing market on what low and middle-income earners can afford and remove the investors on the housing market or people just making a lot of money by having a lot of properties.
from 10 citizens (Petition No. EN2566)
Veterans

The Veterans Entitlement Act 1986 (VEA) has been drafted in such a manner as to provide the Repatriation Medical Authority (RMA) the power to create a Statement of Principal (SoP), into an injury or disease.

On 28 August 2020 the RMA decided not to create a SoP into "being obese", as it considers that, "the point at which people become symptomatic from increased fat mass by itself is the most appropriate test for whether or not obesity is a disease or injury".
"Being obese" is a factor "in 72 conditions, including cardiovascular diseases, various types of cancer, musculoskeletal conditions and some psychiatric conditions".

It is crystal clear the RMA feel the appropriate point at which obesity should be a treatable condition, is when the Veteran becomes symptomatic of one of the many sequella conditions related to obesity, including "cardiovascular diseases, various types of cancer, musculoskeletal conditions and some psychiatric conditions".

Logic would suggest that treating obesity at the earliest point it is identified, may actually prevent such conditions as, "cardiovascular diseases, various cancers, musculoskeletal conditions and some psychiatric conditions" from occurring.
Quotes from Chairperson, RMA, 28 August 2020.

We therefore ask the House to initiate such processes, that will cause such an amendment to the VEA that will result in the RMA being required to create a SoP into "obesity", whether obesity be determined to be a disease or injury within the meaning of section 5D of the VEA or not.
from 18 citizens (Petition No. EN2567)
Olympic and Paralympic Games

The xxiv winter olympics in Beijing in 2022 will draw athletes diplomats and corporations to a country universally recognised as responsible for ongoing crimes against humanity and a raft of human rights abuses including imprisonment without trial against journalists ,lawyers publishers and anyone critical of the regime.
The genocide of the CCP regime against the 12 million Uyghurs of Xinjiang is well documented and acknowledged.
Also acknowledged is the widespread persecution of Falun Gong practitioners, Christians and all dissidents and the attempted obliteration of Tibetan culture .

The CCP regime has engaged in aggressive expansionism in the South China Sea and north east region of India, has crushed the democratic aspirations of the people of Hong Kong and threatens the freedom and democracy of the people of Taiwan.
In view of these developments it would be highly inappropriate for the world's democracies to participate in the 2022 Beijing Olympics while genocide is taking place in Xinjiang.
In February the Canadian Parliament set an example for the world by passing a resolution calling for the removal of the 2022 Olympics from Beijing .

We therefore ask the House to pass a resolution calling for the IOC to remove the 2022 Winter Olympics from Beijing and express its support for a boycott of the Olympics by the Australian Olympic team.
from 13 citizens (Petition No. EN2572)
Commonwealth Electoral Act

It has been proven that there are many fraudulent & illegal votes just a few illegal votes could influence elections. Further mail voting should be ONLY allowed if you're unable to turn out to polling booths or you're sick or overseas.
We therefore ask the House to Mandatory ID at elections with mail voting for special circumstances only (sick & unable to turn out at polling booth, overseas)
from 7 citizens (Petition No. EN2574)
Veterans

The Veterans Entitlement Act 1986 (VEA) has been drafted in such a manner as to provide the Repatriation Medical Authority (RMA) with the power to decide whether or not it creates a Statement of Principal (SoP), into an injury or disease. VEA s5D defines injury and disease.
Each SoP lists the factors, at least one of which "must exist before it can be said that, (an injury or disease) is connected with the circumstances of a person's relevant service".

A perceived anomaly lay in the fact that a condition can be a factor to an injury or disease, and the RMA is not compelled to create a SoP for this condition. A known condition may be a factor in many SoP's.

Creating a SoP for these conditions, will allow for a person to receive appropriate treatment for that condition once it has been accepted as being connected to a person's service, and it will also allow for streamlined, perhaps even immediate acceptance of any, and all of the sequella injuries or illnesses as they occur.

We therefore ask the House to initiate such processes to cause such amendment to the VEA that will result in RMA being compelled to create a SoP for all condition, which exist as a standalone factor, or within a factor in any existing SoP, whether that condition itself, be a disease or injury within the existing meaning of s5D of the VEA or not.
from 28 citizens (Petition No. EN2581)
Government Bonds

There is ample evidence that Australia is overpopulated. Biodiversity is in rapid and catastrophic decline, we are not meeting our emissions targets, and we have incidents of chronic overcrowding impacting our everyday lives.

When investing in government bonds, Australian's should be informed of all the risks that may impact on their returns and how those risks are being managed. Therefore, bond holders should be informed of how demographic risk may affect their returns and how the Federal Government is mitigating those risks.
We therefore ask the House to require Treasury to disclose the risk of human overpopulation to Australian Government Bond returns and how this risk is being managed.
from 1 citizen (Petition No. EN2582)
Superannuation

There is ample evidence that Australia is overpopulated. Biodiversity is in rapid and catastrophic decline, we are not meeting our emissions targets, and overcrowding is having a terrible impact on our everyday lives.
Superannuation funds should be required to disclose how human overpopulation risks may affect member's returns and how funds are managing those risks.
We therefore ask the House to require superannuation funds to disclose how human overpopulation risk may affect super returns and how funds are managing these risks.
from 1 citizen (Petition No. EN2583)
National Education Standards

The national curriculum includes relationships and sexuality as one of its key focus areas. One of the aims of this focus area is to provide adolescents with the tools they need to make informed choices; however, information on the environmental impact of procreation is absent from the curriculum.

Australia is overpopulated. Our biodiversity is in rapid and catastrophic decline, we are not making the emissions reductions necessary to meet our international obligations, and our community is suffering from chronic overcrowding.

On emissions, Prof. Chaurasia (2020) notes that population growth has cancelled out the efforts to reduce emissions to a significant degree, and Wynes and Nicholas (2017) both noted that the most effective way to reduce your carbon footprint is to have fewer children.

Adolescents should be fully informed on the impact having children has on the environment, and the state of the world their children would likely inherit, so that they can make a fully informed decision whether or not to procreate.
We therefore ask the House to include environmental concerns as part of the relationships and sexuality module of the national curriculum.
from 3 citizens (Petition No. EN2584)
Veterans

Veterans that have sole entitlement and eligibility under the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation (Defence-related Claims) Act 1988 (DRCA), are being significantly disadvantaged by comparison to those persons with, Veterans Entitlement Act 1986 (VEA) or Military Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 2004 (MRCA) entitlement, in that the DRCA does not accommodate provision of a "Gold Card".

The Gold Card can best simply be explained, as, providing an entitled person virtually unrestricted treatment to all medical conditions, be they as a result of defence service or not, who suffers significant or compounding injury or disease, as a result of their defence service.

Timewise, broadly speaking, DRCA entitlement resides between the two other Veterans legislation, and it defies logic that a person is being deprived provision of a Gold Card, when another person with comparative injuries and/or illnesses, who enlisted earlier or later, has Gold Card entitlement.

The Gold Card was reintroduced under MRCA, and this leads to the conclusion that the legislators, for whatever reason erred in not including a Gold Card provision under DRCA, and this is now clearly not reflective of public intent or spirit. The decision to deprive Gold Card entitlement to those under DRCA can now be viewed as regressive and unreasonable, and it had an arguably unintended and overly harsh consequence.

We therefore ask the House to initiate such processes to cause amendment to the DRCA that will result in person with DRCA entitlement to be provided a Gold Card, where a disease or injury mirrors their MRCA counterpart.
from 268 citizens (Petition No. EN2585)
Interactive Gambling Act

In 2017 the Australian Government amended the Interactive Gambling Act (2001) to ensure online poker could not be provided to Australian citizens, while still allowing sports betting and wagering (which we see advertised during every sport shown on television).

Poker is a sport. A game of skill that many people play professionally and make their living from. It's a sport that has been affected by covid due to closures of Casino poker rooms and disrupted travel. Events and tournaments have been cancelled, and the closure of our national borders has made it impossible to attend international events.
In a COVID-normal world it seems only reasonable that the Australian Government allows online poker to return to Australia for three key reasons:
1. It will support the sportspeople that make a living from Poker, and in turn support their families and loved ones.
2. It will provide additional tax revenue to the Australian Government which will assist in supporting a post-COVID economy.
3. It will reduce the need for travel by those who consider the sport their full-time job.

We therefore ask the House to amend the Interactive Gambling Act (2001) to allow online poker providers to offer their services in Australia once again to help support the sportspeople that make a living from poker and contribute additional economic support to the Australian economy.
from 199 citizens (Petition No. EN2592)
Gambling

Gambling has been known to have a negative effect on a person's financial wealth, their mental health, it is socially destructive, and can destroy families and individual's lives when a person becomes addicted.
Children are being subjected to continuous advertising campaigns during such times as the News, prime time shows and football matches; and are learning that it's ok to gambles one's savings.

General gambling ads for pokies and the like are not permitted on television, yet betting ads are allowed. All gambling has the potential to affect a person's social and mental health, therefore all gambling ads should be banned, and shouldn't be selective.
We therefore ask the House to ban ALL forms of gambling/betting ads on television and radio.
from 270 citizens (Petition No. EN2593)
Foreign Investment

I find that foreign ownership of land in Australia is of great concern to many, if not all Australian citizens. This grants power and control to foreign citizens and agents on Australian soil. I find it even more disturbing that foreigners are not allowed to own land in many countries where these foreign landowners are from. An example of the downside of such a thing is that is currently hindering the ability of many Australians from owning a home.

We therefore ask the House to outright ban all foreign ownership of Australian land, record it into law and for citizens/corporations/Australian interested parties to repurchase the land from these foreign landowners and to never allow such a thing to happen again.
from 54 citizens (Petition No. EN2594)
Gambling

Gambling is a serious issue for Australians of all ages and the constant advertising of sports betting apps and websites across all media both traditional and online is creating a society where the norm is to bet no matter what you are doing or where you are. There is no need for these websites to advertise, and by doing so they are putting new generations at risk.

We therefore ask the House to bring into effect an advertising ban similar to that faced by cigarette companies, in that they can no longer advertise on any medium or sponsor sporting events at any level across any sport in Australia, and that media that do not meet that expectation face fines and potential legal action.
from 22 citizens (Petition No. EN2595)
Parliament

The Parliament of Australia stands as the peak government institution in the nation. However, frequent scandals which reveal unsavoury and illegal activity by Parliamentarians and their staff have caused the people of Australia to lose faith in the Parliament, the people who work there and the offices they hold. By contrast the majority of Australian workplaces provide a much higher standard of Work Health and Safety. It is considered best practice for business to develop and publicise its own code of conduct and hold its officers accountable for their actions against that code. The people of Australia should expect no less from its highest institution and its representatives.

We therefore ask the House to immediately: (1) Develop and publicise its own code of conduct. (2) Ensure that the code provides meaningful and substantial penalties for both Parliamentarians and their staff for not adhering to the code. (3) Ensure that the code includes as a minimum: (a) using your role for personal gain, or to advantage your political party, or for the benefit of a third party outside of an open competitive process (b) promoting Parliament as a professional place of work which does not condone the use of alcohol or drugs during work hours nor tolerate sex or sexual mistreatment of any kind within its walls. (4) Create an independent and autonomous body to investigate potential breaches of the code and implement penalties prescribed under the code.
from 17 citizens (Petition No. EN2597)
Vaccination
According to the ABS, "From 1 January to 24 November 2020, there have been 42 deaths due to influenza". That's 0.033% of all deaths or 0.00016% of the Australian population.

The government is forcing the conditions whereby residential aged care facilities must refuse entry to anyone who has not vaccinated. This means that if you wish to see your dying relative/remain employed, you have to get vaccinated first.
This is apparently justified due to the fight against COVID19. However, there is no requirement to get COVID19 vaccines. Why is that?
According to the Australian Immunisation Handbook (Department of Health);
"For consent to be legally valid… It must be given voluntarily in the absence of undue pressure, coercion or manipulation."

In response to petition EN1528, Richard Colbeck stated "However, all vaccines used within Australia provide benefits which greatly outweigh their risks". This is not true and can be demonstrated by the removal of recommendation for those under 50 to receive the Astrazeneca vaccine. This is due to the risk being greater for vaccine damage than the disease itself. It was considered "safe", meeting "highest standards" until it wasn't!
The AZ example demonstrates that there are risks. Whenever there is risk, a person must have choice free from coercion.
In order to possibly protect (VE scores are poor) an extremely small percentage of the population, mandatory vaccines violate freedom of choice, informed CONSENT and bodily autonomy.
We therefore ask the House to abide by principles of informed consent. Remove compulsory, coercive influenza vaccination requirements/recommendations in RACF's
from 27 citizens (Petition No. EN2598)
Parliament

In answering petition EN2215 petitioners asked to name pentecostal members of parliament. Mr Smith the Speaker replied saying under S116 of the Constitution no religious test is required as qualification for public office.

At the start of each day prayers are made in Parliament which is in contravention of S116 of the constitution. It says The Commonwealth shall not make any law for establishing any religion, or for imposing any religious observance.
Standing orders say that a prayer must happen. Standing orders are understood to be a law governing how Parliament is run.
Acknowledgement of country is not a prayer.
We therefore ask the House to remove prayers from standing orders.
from 87 citizens (Petition No. EN2599)
Housing Affordability

With the removal of the cost of land from the CPI (in 1998), CPI does not accurately capture the cost of living for many Australians. As CPI is not accurate, the RBA's targeting of inflation cannot be accurate and therefore only further drives housing prices up.
Our wages do not keep up with inflation because inflation isn't accurately measured.
Wealth inequality is a direct result of government/RBA policies. Attempts to save are crippled by QE policies which are essentially a hidden tax on the poor.
There can be no doubt that housing has become unaffordable for an increasing amount of Australians.
Since 1998, private debt to GDP has risen from 130 to around 200%.

For those who own assets it has been a free ride at the expense of those without. Ifinkeeping money in the bank you actually lose value, something is very wrong! When the young dream of a housing crash, something is extremely wrong!

We therefore ask the House to include the cost of land in the CPI, tighten lending standards and pressure the RBA to increase cash rate. While this will mean a reduction in asset values and a likely reverse wealth-effect, these assets are only being kept up due to artificial measures. Young Australians require realistic goals. One of the most important goals is to own a home in order to raise a family. For decades, the government/RBA has increasingly trodden on the dreams and aspirations of the young. Please stop!
from 8 citizens (Petition No. EN2600)
Pensions and Benefits

The Earth is overpopulated. Australia is overpopulated. Residents of Australia should not receive any family tax benefits, childcare subsidies, baby bonuses or any other benefit for having more than one child.
We therefore ask the House to abolish government benefits for having more than one child.
from 8 citizens (Petition No. EN2602)

subdebateinfo.title: Convention on the Rights of the Child

p.span: Convention on the Rights of the Child

A complaint under the Convention of the Rights of the Child can be brought only against a State that satisfies two conditions. First, it must be a party (through ratification or accession) to the treaty that provides for the rights which have allegedly been violated. Second, the State party must have recognized the competence of the Committee monitoring the treaty to receive and consider complaints from individuals.

Australia should follow other signatories to the Convention on the Rights of the Child by recognizing the competence of the Committee on the Rights of the Child to monitor the Convention on the Rights of the Child.
We therefore ask the House to ensure that Australia recognizes the competence of the Committee on the Rights of the Child to monitor the Convention on the Rights of the Child.
from 6 citizens (Petition No. EN2603)
Telecommunications

The Universal Service Obligation entitles Australians to equitable access to standard telephone services (STS). The National Relay Service is the equivalent of STS for people with communication disabilities.

Registration is for the purpose of identifying users, who they are calling, and to prevent misuse by hearing people. Compulsory registration is a fair use control which is discriminatory, inequitable, adds to existing barriers, administration and cost.

Australians without disability don't have to register or prove eligibility to use STS, and have the choice to disable Caller ID. The privacy of call content and caller identity is protected by law, except for emergency calls.

NRS users won't have their choices or privacy respected after April 20; and have to register personal details and a telephone number they must use to identify themselves for every call made. Any calls made will be recorded against their account.

A 2016 consultation discussed limiting or stopping the NRS to make it sustainable. This information was not available in Auslan until weeks after publication which limited Auslan users from responding within the timeframe. There were 25 submissions with 12 mentioning registration. Most submissions were from companies, not users. The overall view of registration was unfavourable. Where registration was considered acceptable, it was in the context of vulnerable people not wanting to lose access to an essential service.
Forced registration is not allowing for an informed choice to be made, free of duress with human rights principles in mind.
We therefore ask the House to make NRS registration a choice!
from 39 citizens (Petition No. EN2604)
Veterans

The introduction of the Australian Veterans' Recognition (Putting Veterans and Their Families First) Act (AVRA) 2019 commits decisions makers to deciding claims "within a time that is proportionate to the complexity of the matter", however this wording has the effect of this commitment being nothing more than tokenistic.

The VEA arms those investigating and deciding claims with considerable power, including summons and subpoena, and the ability to effectively force the Applicant/Claimant to a medical examination. The introduction of the Statement of Principals in 1994 had the effect of considerably limiting the scope of VEA s17 investigations to the factors within the SoP, those conducting s17 investigations now have electronic access to records, and processing of documentation is now largely electronic.

Untimeliness in investigating and determining claims under the Veterans' Entitlement Act (VEA) 1986 has become a significant and unacceptable issue, and there is no reason why this should be the case as these claims and applications are not complex.

Introduction of a statute timeframe would enable the Claimant/Applicant to engage Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977, Section 7, Applications in respect of failures to make decisions, Subsection 2 and provide a pathway via the Federal Court to have decision made, and thus add some substance to the commitment Parliament made under the AVRA.
We therefore ask the House to initiate such processes that will result in amendment to the VEA and result in 60 days being the statute time frame for claims and applications to be decided.
from 33 citizens (Petition No. EN2605)
Women's Economic Security

The Gender Pay Gap persists despite the passage of Equal Opportunity Legislation, 1975; Workplace Gender Equality Act 2012; Fair Work Act 2009; Sex Discrimination Act 1984. Reductions in the gap post COVID-19 are because of lower paid men re-entering the workforce, not gains by women.

Over their lifetimes, women will earn less than men; are less likely to advance their careers as far as men; accumulate less superannuation and savings than men; and are more likely to live in poverty in old age.

The gap between women's and men's earnings reflects the historic and systemic undervaluing of women's workplace contributions and the significant barriers that lead to the under-representation of women in senior executive and management roles.

A lack of respect and undervaluing of women including their paid and unpaid work is at the heart of all forms of discrimination against women and gender inequality, violence against women and coercive control.
Structural and legislative change is required because other efforts have failed.
We therefore ask the House to introduce a Bill to legislate for:
• The requirement for employers to certify equal remuneration for all employees, contractors, outworkers etc;
• Oversight, certification, remediation and sanctions by an appropriate organisation such as Fair Work Commission, WGEA, Australian Human Rights Commission and where necessary by a federal court;
• Strengthened remedies for unequal remuneration with appropriate redress under Fair Work Agreements or Sex Discrimination Act (1984)
The legislation should ascribe equal value to work performed in female dominated occupations and in male dominated occupations.
from 441 citizens (Petition No. EN2607)
COVID 19: Vaccination

Investigate the reactions and side effects from the AstraZeneca vaccine which has rolled by the Australian Government. Even after this individual vaccine has been ceased use from other countries because multiple adverse reactions.

We therefore ask the House to cease the AstraZeneca vaccine roll out until proven clinical studies can provide a safe and proven vaccine that will have no proven adverse reactions to any Australian citizen.
from 77 citizens (Petition No. EN2609)
COVID-19: International Travel

It has been more than a year since International Borders were closed. The citizens of Australia has a basic right to see their parents and families overseas. It is not humane for the government to keep families away. A system needs to be created in which families can see each other again.
We therefore ask the House to partially open international borders to be able to have parents come into Australia from overseas or citizens travel solely to visit parents.
from 1837 citizens (Petition No. EN2611)
Food Labelling
There are possible malpractices in issuance of halal certification and an equal possibility of financial corruption based on the recent findings by a non-profit organization
- Concern in the Muslim community of Australia about the meat they consume whether it meets the high standards and undergoes a scrutinized process
- No governance of halal certification for local businesses leading to corruption including self-certifying as halal and tarnishing the reputation of similar businesses with a similar supplier
We therefore ask the House to

Introduction of authority or overseeing body governing the issuance of Halal certificates, in a similar way to the Islamic bodies regulating red meat for export. This will make the process of obtaining halal certificates more transparent and streamlined.
from 83 citizens (Petition No. EN2612)
PETITIONS
Responses
Mr O'DOWD (Flynn—Deputy Nationals Whip) (10:01): I present the following ministerial responses to petitions previously presented:
Perth Airport
Dear Mr O'Dowd

I am writing in relation to petition number EN1823, concerning the Perth Airport Master Plan 2020 and pending Major Development Plans approvals, including environmental approvals, submitted by the Wildflower Society of Western Australia.

All leased Federal airports (except for Tennant Creek and Mount Isa) are subject to a planning framework outlined in the Airports Act 1996 (the Airports Act) and are required to prepare a Master Plan (MP) that incorporates an Environment Strategy. The MP is a 20 year strategic vision for the airport site which is renewed every five years. The MP includes future land uses, types of permitted development, and noise and environmental impacts. The Environment Strategy sets out the airports strategy to manage environmental issues.

Airports must publish a Preliminary Draft MP and invite public comment. During this public consultation period, airports are required under the Airports Act to accept submissions from public stakeholders raising any concerns about the MP. Following the public consultation, the airport must submit a Draft MP to me, as the Minister for Infrastructure and Regional Development, for a decision.

This Draft MP must include all submissions received by the airport and how the airport has addressed the issues raised. I must either approve or refuse to approve the Draft MP based on the advice. I note that the Wildflower Society of Western Australia did not make a submission raising their concerns to the Perth Airport during the MP public consultation period, which was open from 24 July 2019 to 18 October 2019.

In addition, all leased Federal airports are required to develop a Major Development Plan (MDP) for major airport developments. A draft version of the MDP must also undergo public consultation before being submitted to me for a decision.

As with the MP process, airports are required to provide me with all submissions received during the public consultation period as well as details as to how they have dealt with issues raised. Interested parties are strongly encouraged to make submissions to airports regarding issues they may have with MDPs. This will allow the Airport to give regard to the issues as well as ensuring I, as the decision maker, am aware of these concerns.

An MDP must also set out the environmental impacts that can reasonably be expected and the proponent's proposed measures for dealing with those impacts. Section 94(3)(c) of the Airports Act requires me, in deciding to approve or refuse to approve an MDP, to have regard for "the impact that carrying out the plan would be likely to have on the environment". To inform this decision, the draft MDP is referred to the Minister for the Environment for advice under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 (EPBC Act).

Sections 160(1) and 160(2)(c) of the EPBC Act requires advice be sought and considered from the Environment Minister (or their delegate) on the protection of the environment from major airport developments prior to my decision being made on whether or not to approve an MDP.

Following referral of an exposure draft MDP, the Environment Minister (or their delegate) may decide that advice is not required, if they are satisfied that the referred action does not have, will not have, or is not likely to have a significant impact on the environment. If advice is required, the Environment Minister (or their delegate) will proceed to undertake an environmental assessment and provide advice under the EPBC Act.

Advice received by me from the Environment Minister (or their delegate) concerning the protection of the environment in relation to an MDP may be used to apply conditions on my approval of the MDP. These conditions must be met before building approvals for the development are provided.
Specifically in relation to the MDP for Perth Airport's New Runway project, the Environment Minister provided advice to me which required consideration by the airport to:
the management and minimisation of impacts to protected matters, such as the cockatoo habitat, nesting area, vegetation, identified tree and wetland area;
an Offset Strategy and Offset Management Plan for each offset area to be provided;
a Propagation, Research and Monitoring Plan to be undertaken; and
ensuring each plan was published on the airports' website.

Again, I note that the Wildflower Society of Western Australia did not make a submission outlining their concerns to the Perth Airport during the public consultation period for the MDP for its New Runway project, which was open from 31 May 2018 to 24 August 2018.

In relation to the Independent Review of the EPBC Act, the Australian Government is committed to working with stakeholders on the full detail of the recommendations of the Review. The Review is far reaching and we will continue to work alongside stakeholders as each recommendation is considered. It is important that our legislation is fit to meet the challenges facing our environment and grow the economy.

The Government is committed to a staged program of reforms in response to the EPBC Act Review, starting with implementing single-touch approvals underpinned by national environmental standards and rigorous assurance monitoring. National Cabinet reaffirmed its commitment to this reform in December 2020. Subsequent phases of reform will build on these important early steps, taking into account the recommendations of the EPBC Act Review.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Infrastructure, Transport and Regional Development, Mr McCormack

subdebateinfo.title: Royal Commission into the New South Wales Police Service, National Integrity Commission

p.span: Royal Commission into the New South Wales Police Service
National Integrity Commission
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your email of 10 November 2020 to the former Attorney-General and Minister for Industrial Relations, the Hon Christian Porter MP, regarding Petition EN1856. I welcome the opportunity to respond to this petition.

The petition raises concerns about '90 year suppression orders' that were purportedly made over documents provided to the Commonwealth Royal Commission into Institutional Responses to Child Sexual Abuse. I am advised that no such suppression orders have been made by the Commonwealth Parliament or any federal court. This Government did bring forward amendments to the Royal Commissions Act 1902 to exclude information obtained at a private session from public access for 99 years (section 6OM). The personal and sensitive nature of people's accounts of how they have been affected by child sexual abuse justified this action and it is limited to private session related information.

The petition also raises similar concerns about the Royal Commission into the New South Wales Police Service. This Royal Commission was established by the New South Wales Government, to whom any concerns should be directed.

The petition also raises concerns about corruption in public institutions. The Government has released draft legislation to establish a Commonwealth Integrity Commission (CIC) for public consultation. The CIC will be a centralised, specialist centre for investigating corruption in the federal public sector. The Government is currently considering whether the CIC should have jurisdiction over the federal judiciary. Further information on the CIC is available at https://www.ag.gov.au/integrity/consultations/commonwealth-integrity-commission.
Thank you again for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General and Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cash
Australian Government
Dear Chair

Thank you for your email of 9 November 2020 to the previous Minister for Home Affairs, the Hon Peter Dutton MP, regarding petition number EN1916, which requests that the Commonwealth ensure the majority consent of all citizens before determining State of Disaster/Emergency laws and signing international treaties. As the issues raised fall within my portfolio responsibilities as the Attorney-General and Minister for Industrial Relations, your email was referred to me for reply.
State of Disaster/Emergency laws

Australia's Constitution adopts a federalist model which provides states with a large degree of autonomy over the governance of their own affairs. Some measures adopted in response to the COVID-19 pandemic have been taken under Commonwealth legislation (for example, measures taken under the Biosecurity Act 2015, such as declaring the existence of a human biosecurity emergency under section 475 and subsequent emergency requirements).

A number of state and territory governments have taken their own public health and emergency management measures in response to the pandemic. The Commonwealth has worked closely and co-operatively with these governments, and will continue to seek to work cooperatively with all states and territories to ease restrictions in a safe way.
The Government does not, therefore, propose to enact laws to ensure the majority consent of all citizens in implementing State of Disaster/Emergency laws.
International treaties

Reforms to Australia's treaty-making process in 1996 provided greater visibility and enhanced opportunities for scrutiny of treaties by the Parliament, state and territory governments, non­government organisations and members of the public. These reforms ensured that every Australian individual and interest group with a concern about treaty issues had the opportunity to make that concern known. The Parliamentary Joint Standing Committee on Treaties (JSCOT) was established as part of the 1996 reforms, and it reviews and reports on all treaty actions proposed by the Government. JSCOT advertises its reviews on its website, inviting comments from anyone with an interest in the subject matter of a proposed treaty action. JSCOT routinely takes evidence at public hearings from government agencies and may also invite people who have made written submissions to appear.
The final decision on whether a treaty should be signed and binding treaty action taken is made by the Federal Executive Council, which is the body responsible for advising the Governor­General.
On this basis, the Government does not propose to enact laws to ensure the majority consent of all citizens when signing international treaties.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General and Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cash
Media
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your email of 30 November 2020 to the former Attorney-General and Minister for Industrial Relations, the Hon Christian Porter MP, referring a petition (EN1980) for a Royal Commission into the media entities owned by the Murdoch family.

Royal Commissions are a form of non-judicial and non-administrative governmental investigation and are only established in exceptional circumstances. Commonwealth Royal Commissions are established through the issuing of Letters Patent by the Governor-General under the Royal Commissions Act 1902 (Cth). It is the Government of the day that determines the need to request a Royal Commission.

I understand that the Minister for Communications, Urban Infrastructure, Cities and the Arts wrote to you on 30 January 2021 in respect of petition (EN1938), which is of a similar character to the present petition.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General and Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cash
Members of Parliament: Conduct
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your letter dated 30 November 2020 referring petition EN1982 relating to Australia's political funding and disclosure framework. I am responding as the Assistant Minister for Electoral Matters. I apologise for the delay in my response.

Australia has a longstanding history of conducting free and fair elections which ensures Australians enjoy the freedom to engage in democratic discourse that is consistent with the implied freedom of political communication under the Australian Constitution. Participation in this process includes Australians financially supporting candidates and political parties of their choice through political donations.

The Government has taken action to strengthen funding and disclosure requirements, including through the Electoral Legislation Amendment (Electoral Funding and Disclosure Reform) Act 2018 which introduced a Transparency Register to Australia's electoral framework which contains information about political parties, candidates and other participants in the electoral process who are registered with or recognised by the Australian Electoral Commission (AEC). The register includes annual returns, returns during election campaigns and election funding claims and is publically available at https://transparency.aec.gov.au. Additionally, this Act banned foreign political donations and prohibited the use of foreign money for electoral expenditure. The AEC conducts compliance reviews of the disclosure of political donations and campaign expenditure, to ensure candidates and political parties adhere with Australia's comprehensive electoral transparency framework.

The Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters (JSCEM) is holding an inquiry into the operation of the Electoral Legislation Amendment (Election Funding and Disclosure Reform Act) 2018. The Government will consider recommendations from JSCEM once this report is tabled in Parliament, expected in May 2021.
Thank you for bringing the matters referred to in this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister for Electoral Matters, Mr Morton
Welfare
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your email dated 15 February 2021 to the former Minister for the National Disability Insurance Scheme and the Minister for Government Services, the Hon Stuart Robert MP, concerning petition EN2045 and a pilot program to test the feasibility of implementing a program such as Universal Basic Income. As the matter raised falls within my portfolio responsibility, your email has been forwarded to me for reply.

The Australian welfare system is designed to provide a safety net to individuals while encouraging self-provision whenever possible. Targeting through income and asset testing focuses assistance on those most in need, while ensuring the Government is able to meet other important budgetary objectives, such as spending on health and education, while keeping taxes low.

A universal payment for all Australians would impact the government's ability to maintain a fiscally sustainable safety net for individuals in future and would result in taxpayer-funded support being provided to people who may have considerable private means. Moving from a highly-targeted welfare system to a universal, non-means tested system would also increase income inequality in Australia.

The Government is committed to a welfare system that supports the most vulnerable, encourages those who are able to work or study, is sustainable and is able to be responsive, including to provide temporary measures to cushion the impact of the pandemic and through permanent changes to strengthen Australia's income support system.
Thank you again for raising this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Families and Social Services, Senator Ruston
Ex-Offenders: Ban the Box Campaign
Dear Chair

Thank you for your email of 15 February 2021 to the former Attorney-General and Minister for Industrial Relations, the Hon Christian Porter MP, referring Petition EN2071, about banning employers from asking for a person's criminal history in recruitment processes.

Discrimination against a person on the basis of their criminal record is not generally unlawful in recruitment processes under Commonwealth, state and territory anti-discrimination legislation where a person's criminal history is relevant to the inherent requirements of a particular position. This is also reflected in the general protections of the Fair Work Act 2009, which regulates the national industrial relations framework. The only jurisdictions that currently prohibit discrimination on the basis of irrelevant criminal record are Tasmania and the Northern Territory.

This position reflects the reality that there are legislative requirements in some employment contexts, for instance for those persons seeking to work with children, where you may be unable to be employed if you have a certain criminal record. In addition, some professional and occupational licensing bodies have considered the special characteristics of their field and developed licensing and registration rules which address the relevance of a person's criminal record to that profession.

While discrimination on this basis is not prohibited, the Australian Human Rights Commission (AHRC) has the right to conduct an inquiry into any complaint of criminal record discrimination under the equal opportunity in employment provisions of the Australian Human Rights Commission Act 1986 (Cth).

If the AHRC considers that the act or practice the subject of the complaint was discriminatory or inconsistent with human rights, the AHRC must report to the Attorney-General in relation to the inquiry and this report must be tabled in Parliament. This is the case provided a settlement was not appropriate or successful.

The Government is of the view that the current legal framework strikes an appropriate balance between allowing those with criminal records to find employment while ensuring employers can refuse to employ someone where their criminal record makes them unsuitable in the position for which they have applied.

Spent convictions schemes and privacy laws in Australia interact with this framework to respectively limit what can be disclosed to employers in a recruitment process about a person's criminal history and how this personal information can be collected and used by employers.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General and Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cash
COVID-19: Income Support Payments
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your email dated 15 February 2021 to the former Minister for Government Services, the Hon Stuart Robert MP, concerning petition number EN2087 regarding social security payments. As the matter raised falls within my portfolio responsibilities, the petition has been forwarded to me for consideration.

The Australian Government has stood side by side with all Australians during the coronavirus pandemic and will continue to do so through permanent changes to strengthen our income support system. These measures are intended to provide jobseekers with the best opportunity to secure employment as our nation continues to recover from the economic challenges of COVID-19.

The Government has extended the temporary Coronavirus Supplement until 31 March 2021. From 1 January 2021 to 31 March 2021, the supplement has changed to $150 a fortnight to reflect the gradually improving economic and labour market conditions.

Subject to passage of legislation, from 1 April 2021, the Government is permanently increasing the rate of working age payments by $50 a fortnight. This is in addition to the usual indexation of payments on 20 March 2021. Depending on their circumstances, recipients may also be eligible for supplementary payments, such as Commonwealth Rent Assistance.

Also from 1 April 2021, the Government is changing the income free area for JobSeeker Payment, Parenting Payment Partnered and Youth Allowance (other) to $150 a fortnight. This is an increase to the income free area for JobSeeker Payment and Youth Allowance (other) that applied prior to COVID-19.

Pension payment rates are significantly higher than the JobSeeker Payment rates because recipients have barriers such as age, disability or caring responsibilities that make it harder to support themselves. In addition, they also have the Pensioner Concession Card, which provides access to more concessions than the Health Care Card that people on JobSeeker Payment have.

The Australian social security system is a taxpayer-funded, non-contributory system based on the concepts of residence and need. For this reason, to be eligible for most social security payments, a person must satisfy the definition of an Australian resident for the purposes of the Social Security Act 1991 and be in Australia at the time of their claim. Migrants arriving in Australia from overseas are usually subject to a four-year Newly Arrived Residents Waiting Period.
